answers.title: Error installing docker on other partition

answers.body_markdown:
The way you are trying to install docker on another partition is not correct.

- You need a partition (`sdb7` in your case). Suppose its mounted at `/mnt/sdb7`

- Docker by default store all its data (containers, images and so on) in `/var/lib/docker` you need to change this in your case to something like `/mnt/sdb7/docker` using [data-root][1] option of docker.


While starting docker deamon use `--data-root` option.
```
dockerd --data-root=/mnt/sdb7/docker
```

Hope this helps.

**Update:**

The `dockerd` command will run in foreground. 

You need to set `--data-root` option permanently for `docker.service` that you start/stop using `systemctl`.

To set that option permanently refer [this][2].

You need to add this line `"data-root": "/mnt/docker-data"` in `/etc/docker/daemon.json` file.

**Update-2:**

`docker.socket: Failed with result 'service-start-limit-hit'` means docker.service seems to fail and restart to fast. The is explained [here][3].

You need to edit systemd file for docker using `systemctl edit docker.service` as mentioned [here][4] and tweak the values of `StartLimitIntervalSec=` and `StartLimitBurst=` as mentioned [here][3] so that the `docker.service` will not fail to quickly.

**Update-3:**

Editing `/etc/systemd/system.conf` file is dangerous it might cause serious problem with your VM. What I suggested was to change make change using `systemctl edit docker.service`.

The docker.service systemd file contents should be similar to [this][5].
Also refer [this][6].


  [1]: https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/dockerd/#run-multiple-daemons
  [2]: https://docs.docker.com/config/daemon/systemd/#custom-docker-daemon-options
  [3]: https://serverfault.com/questions/845471/service-start-request-repeated-too-quickly-refusing-to-start-limit
  [4]: https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/33931#issuecomment-453840775
  [5]: https://github.com/moby/moby/blob/master/contrib/init/systemd/docker.service
  [6]: https://docs.docker.com/config/daemon/systemd/#manually-create-the-systemd-unit-files

answers.body_markdown:
To get the first nested value, one solution would be to use `REGEXP_REPLACE()` to remove the unwanted parts of the string.

I would suggest the following regex: `(^\\[)|(")|(,.*)`. Basically this will match on:

- the opening bracket
- OR the double quotes
- OR everything after the first comma

Consider:

    SELECT REGEXP_REPLACE(
        '["some text - more text & text","some other text - more text & text"]',
      '(^\\[)|(")|(,.*)',
      ''
     ) new_value;

**[Demo on DB Fiddle](https://www.db-fiddle.com/f/mPsKJZXBHz3v4JokyfLaui/1)**:

    | new_value                    |
    | ---------------------------- |
    | some text - more text & text |
answers.title: Selecting string pattern with REGEX from table column in mySQL

Maybe i wasn't clear in my cooemnt.
When take this Table

    CREATE TABLE table1 
    (`id` int , `txtarray`  varchar(200))
     ;
    
    INSERT INTO table1
        (`id`  , `txtarray` )
    VALUES
        (1, '["some text - more text & text","some other text - more text & text","some other1 text - more text & text"]'),
        (2, '["some1 text - more text & text","some other2 text - more text & text","some other3 text - more text & text"]')
    ;

and use following Select statement

    SELECT
      REPLACE(SUBSTRING_INDEX(
        SUBSTRING_INDEX(p.txtarray, ',', N.n + 1)
        , ',', -1
       ),'"','') AS part
       ,p.ID
    FROM (SELECT @n := @n + 1 AS n
       FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS AS a
       CROSS JOIN INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS AS b
       CROSS JOIN (SELECT @n := -1) AS I
       WHERE @n < 1000) N 
      CROSS JOIN (Select id, REPLACE(REPLACE(txtarray,'[',''),']','') txtarray 
                  From table1) p
        WHERE 
          N.n <= (LENGTH(p.txtarray) - LENGTH(REPLACE(p.txtarray, ',', ''));

You get following result.

    part 	                                ID
    some text - more text & text 	        1
    some1 text - more text & text 	        2
    some other text - more text & text 	    1
    some other2 text - more text & text 	2
    some other1 text - more text & text 	1

answers.body_markdown:
As I understand your question, you just want to read the first string. Since your value looks like a valid JSON array, you can just use the following:

    select str->'$[0]' from my_table;

This however requires MySQL 5.7 or above.

See [demo](https://www.db-fiddle.com/f/kp1TgKj6bwpof7Qne33ChK/0)

If you want to normalize your data in a new table - Consider the following script (Requires MySQL 8.0):

Assuming you have this data:

    create table my_table (
      id int,
      str text
    );
    
    insert into my_table (id, str) values
      (1, '["some text - more text & text","some other text - more text & text"]'),
      (2, '["text 2-1","text 2-2","text 2-3"]');

Create a new normalized table:

    create table my_normalized_table(
      id int,
      pos int,
      str text
    );

And copy the data with:

    insert into my_normalized_table (id, pos, str)
      with recursive seq as (
        select 0 as n
        union all
        select n + 1
        from seq
        where n < 99
      )
        select t.id, s.n, json_extract(t.str, replace('$[n]', 'n', s.n)) as str
        from seq s
        cross join my_table t
        having str is not null
    ;

Note: I'm assuming you have at most 100 strings in the array. If you can have more, you need to adjust `where n < 99`.

The new table will contain:

    | id  | pos | str                                  |
    | --- | --- | ------------------------------------ |
    | 1   | 0   | "some text - more text & text"       |
    | 2   | 0   | "text 2-1"                           |
    | 1   | 1   | "some other text - more text & text" |
    | 2   | 1   | "text 2-2"                           |
    | 2   | 2   | "text 2-3"                           |

[View on DB Fiddle](https://www.db-fiddle.com/f/8oCYnYD9feHo5FtA9ivpRD/0)

If your production server has an older MySQL version, you can still export the old table, import it on a MySQL 8.0 server, run the script, export the new table and import it in the production server.

A `Graph` is an undirected graph, where `(1, 13)` and `(13, 1)` mean the same thing, the edges have no 'arrows'.

What you want is a `DiGraph`, meaning a directed graph. See https://networkx.github.io/documentation/stable/reference/classes/index.html

An `OrderedGraph` is something else - it just means that when you iterate over nodes and edges, they come out in a particular order (similar to lists vs sets).

answers.body_markdown:
Because `cd` doesn't read parameters from standard-in, it takes them as arguments.

However you could do this...

    cd `echo mypath`

Which uses backticks (``) to resolve echo mypath into a string and pass that as an argument to cd.

I presume you are trying to use something more elaborate than echo of course, because the above is exactly equivalent to `cd mypath`.

For further info look up "pipelining".  The pipe operator "|" takes the standard-out text stream from one process and feeds it into the standard-in stream of another.  `cd` simply does not read from it's standard-in stream, that's all.

answers.body_markdown:
In Python 3.7 or less, you can do this using the following combination of list comprehensions + generator expression:

    stats = [sum(score) - min(score) for score in ([random.randint(1, 6) for n in range(4)] for stat in range(6))]

In Python 3.8 (still in beta), you can do it in a simpler way thanks to the new [`walrus`](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0572/#syntax-and-semantics) assignment operator:

    stats = [sum(score := [random.randint(1, 6) for n in range(4)]) - min(score) for stat in range(6)]

You can try it [here][1].

 [1]: https://tio.run/##K6gsycjPM7YoKPr/PzO3IL@oRKEoMS8lP5eruCSxpFjBViG6uDRXozg5vyhVwQrIg8jqgajMvBINQx0FM02FtPwihTyFzDyQ3vRUDRPNWE0FXYXczDyIRogCkIEINWaasVwFRSAjwBZp/v8PAA

Testing both approaches:

###Comprehensions (`<=`Python 3.7):

    import random
    
    random.seed(1)
    
    stats = [sum(score) - min(score) for score in ([random.randint(1, 6) for n in range(4)] for stat in range(6))]
    
    print(stats)

Output:

    [10, 12, 12, 12, 15, 14]

###Comprehensions + walrus (Python 3.8):

    import random
    
    random.seed(1)
    
    stats = [sum(score := [random.randint(1, 6) for n in range(4)]) - min(score) for stat in range(6)]
    
    print(stats)

Output:

    [10, 12, 12, 12, 15, 14]

answers.body_markdown:
You can use cameras near/far clipping planes (Frustum Culling) to adjust the distance for rendering. 
If you are looking for something more advanced use [occlusion culling][1] or combination of both:

> Occlusion Culling is a feature that disables rendering of objects when they are not currently seen by the camera
 because they are obscured (occluded) by other objects. This does not happen automatically in 3D computer graphics since most of the time objects farthest away from the camera are drawn first and closer objects are drawn over the top of them (this is called “overdraw”). Occlusion Culling is different from Frustum Culling. Frustum Culling only disables the renderers for objects that are outside the camera’s viewing area but does not disable anything hidden from view by overdraw. Note that when you use Occlusion Culling you will still benefit from Frustum Culling.

You can also use [Camera.layerCullDistances][2] if you want different camera cull distances for different objects:

> Normally Camera skips rendering of objects that are further away than farClipPlane. You can set up some Layers to use smaller culling distances using layerCullDistances. This is very useful to cull small objects early on, if you put them into appropriate layers.




  [1]: https://docs.unity3d.com/Manual/OcclusionCulling.html
  [2]: https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Camera-layerCullDistances.html

answers.body_markdown:
I don't know how you get the values that you expect.  But if you want the proportion of *all* users, then the `sum(cnt)` is throwing you off.  The query should look more like this:

    SELECT date(time) as typical_day, activityname, cnt,
           count(distinct userid) as counting,
           count(distinct userid) / cnt * 100 percentage
    FROM activity_entries ae CROSS JOIN
         (select count(distinct userid) as cnt
          from activity_entries) cd
    WHERE date(time) = '2013-11-01'
    GROUP BY date(time), activityname, cnt;

If you want the proportion of users on a *given* day, then:

    SELECT date(ae.time) as typical_day, ae.activityname, cd.cnt,
           count(distinct ae.userid) as counting,
           count(distinct ae.userid) / cd.cnt * 100 percentage
    FROM activity_entries ae JOIN
         (SELECT date(time) as date,
                 COUNT(distinct userid) as cnt
          FROM activity_entries
          GROUP BY date(time)
         ) cd
         ON date(ae.time) = cd.date
    WHERE date(ae.time) = '2013-11-01'
    GROUP BY date(ae.time), ae.activityname, cd.cnt;

answers.body_markdown:
This regex is what you need,

    \d+\.\d+\s+Section[\w\W]+?(?=\R*(?:\d+\.\d+|$))

Explanation to this regex is following,

- `\d+\.\d+` - Matches one or more digits followed by dot followed by one or more digits.
- `\s+Section` - Matches one or more whitespace followed by `Section` word. You can enable `i` flag if you want to make it case insensitive.
- `[\w\W]+?(?=\R*(?:\d+\.\d+|$))` - Captures one or more any characters including newlines as less as possible due to non-greedy (`+?`) capture and stops just before either when it sees an optional new line followed by one or more digits plus a dot followed by one or more digits or end of string.

[Demo url][1]


  [1]: https://regex101.com/r/CLzSfI/1/

The `color` prop is being passed down to your HTML because `color` is an attribute of the `<font>` HTML tag  and thus this is the expected behavior.

Therefore I would avoid using `color` as prop for styled-components/React to avoid passing down unnecessary HTML attributes

answers.title: SQL Server: hidden "Sort" inserted in execution plan in left join query

items.body_markdown:
SQL 2017 Standard
i have a database in a star schema model (data warehouse)
to fill in a fact table, i have a stored procedure with a temporary table having around 470,0000 rows.
to fill in the dimension ids, i have a left join operation between the temporary table and the dimensions  tables.
for ex:
```
insert into factTable (...fields list...)
select t.Quantity1,t.Quantity2,d1.ID,d.ID,...,19.id from
MyTemp t
left outer join dim1 d1 on t.F1=d1.F1 and t.CompanyID=d1.CompanyID and t.DataSourceID=d1.DataSourceID
left outer join dim2 d2 on t.F2=d2.F2 and t.CompanyID=d2.CompanyID and t.DataSourceID=d2.DataSourceID
left outer join dim3 d3 on t.F3=d3.F3 and t.CompanyID=d2.CompanyID and t.DataSourceID=d2.DataSourceID
.......
left outer join dim19 d19 on t.F19=3.F19 and t.CompanyID=d19.CompanyID and t.DataSourceID=d19.DataSourceID
```
the problem is when using a smaller number of joins, for ex just for the first 5 or 6 dimensions, the query is very fast.

with 19 joins, it is taking more than 4 hours.

the execution plan shows that the bottleneck comes from a hidden "Sort" operation inserted by the query optimizer!!!!

when reading data from each dimension,  sql server is sorting the dimension data before joining with the temporary table.
introducing indexes on the temporary table did not solve the problem.
even limiting the query to the first field from an index on the temp table did not help 
  

[![Hidden Sort in execution plan][1]][1]



[![hidden sort - second picture][2]][2]


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/5x5YY.png
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/60du6.png

answers.body_markdown:
> I would like to know the count of subjects solely present under each category but not in other categories.

You can aggregate by patient, keeping track of the categories.  Then aggregate again:

    select visit_type, count(*)
    from (select patientId, min(visit_type) as visit_type
          from t
          group by patientId
          having min(visit_type) = max(visit_type)
         ) p
    group by visit_type;

An alternative method uses `group by` but filters before aggregation:

    select visit_type, count(*)
    from t
    where not exists (select 1
                      from t t2
                      where t2.patientid = t.patientid and
                            t2.visit_type <> t.visit_type
                     )
    group by visit_type;

Note:  In this case, the `count(*)` is counting rows.  If your data has duplicates, use `count(distinct visit_type)`.

I have no idea what "I consider Inpatient category as base category" is supposed to mean, but the question itself is quite clear.

EDIT:

I am unclear on the relationships between the different categories that you want.  You may find it most flexible to use:

    select visit_type, count(*)
    from (select patientId,
                 bool_or(visit_type = 'Inpatient') as has_inpatient,
                 bool_or(visit_type = 'Outpatient') as has_oupatient,
                 bool_or(visit_type = 'Emergency') as has_emergency,
                 count(distinct visit_type) as num_visit_types
          from t
          group by patientId
         ) p
    where num_visit_types = 1
    group by visit_type;

This version is the same as the earlier two queries.  But you can use the `has_` flags for additional filtering -- for instance `where num_visit_types = 1 or (num_visit_types = 2 and has_inpatient)` if you want people with one type or one type plus "inpatient".
answers.title: How to get count of items present in each category but not present in other categories?

answers.body_markdown:
You can use this query!

    SELECT 
        C.visit_type,
        COUNT(*) AS count_per_visit_type
    FROM (
        SELECT
            person_id
        FROM (
            SELECT
                person_id,
                ARRAY_AGG(DISTINCT visit_type) AS visit_type_array
            FROM visit
            GROUP BY person_id
        ) A 
        WHERE LENGTH(visit_type_array) = 1
    ) B
    JOIN visit C
    ON B.person_id = C.person_id
    GROUP BY C.visit_type
answers.title: How to get count of items present in each category but not present in other categories?

answers.body_markdown:
With a `CTE` which returns for each `person_id` all the types:

    with cte as (
      select person_id, 
        sum(case visit_type when 'Inpatient' then 1 else 0 end) Inpatient,
        sum(case visit_type when 'Outpatient' then 1 else 0 end) Outpatient,
        sum(case visit_type when 'Emergency' then 1 else 0 end) Emergency
      from Visit
      group by person_id
    )
    select 
      case 
        when Inpatient > 0 then 'Inpatient' 
        when Outpatient > 0 then 'Outpatient' 
        when Emergency > 0 then 'Emergency'
      end visit_type,
      count(*) counter
    from cte
    group by visit_type
See the [demo][1].<br/>
Results:

    visit_type | counter
    :--------- | ------:
    Outpatient |       2
    Emergency  |       3
    Inpatient  |       4

answers.body_markdown:
To [prettify `Array` printing][1] consider [`ScalaRunTime.stringOf`][2] like so

```
import scala.runtime.ScalaRunTime.stringOf
println(stringOf(ww))
```

which outputs

```
List(Array(Hello, world), Array(How, are, you))
```

As explained by @Dmytro, `Array`s are bit different from other Scala collections such as `List`, and one difference is they are printed as `hashCode` representations 

```
public String toString() {
  return getClass().getName() + "@" + Integer.toHexString(hashCode());
}
```

instead of *value* representations.


  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/a/17635886/5205022
  [2]: https://github.com/scala/scala/blob/a3791d4d61bd584f27e4dac8765f753a27bb95e0/src/library/scala/runtime/ScalaRunTime.scala#L166

Perhaps [mkString](https://alvinalexander.com/scala/scala-convert-array-to-string-mkstring) is what you are looking for?

    scala> val ww2 = words.map(line=>line.split("_").mkString(","))
    ww2: List[String] = List(Hello,world, How,are,you)
    
    scala> println(ww2)
    List(Hello,world, How,are,you)

answers.body_markdown:
The problem that you are seeing is that celery is using the same "broker" in both project 1 and project 2.  In order to use two different celery projects simultaneously, all you have to do is give them different brokers.  You can specify a broker using the [`broker_url` setting](https://docs.celeryproject.org/en/latest/userguide/configuration.html#broker-settings).  

We typically use redis as a broker, so it is very simple to put one project on redis db 0 and the other project on redis db 1.  That said, there is a lot of [thinking that normally goes into which broker to use](https://docs.celeryproject.org/en/latest/getting-started/brokers/), and deciding on a broker is outside the scope of this particular question.

answers.body_markdown:
There are two more differences between your queries:

1. From python you have `05 00` and from dig you have `10 00` as "[UDP Payload Size][1]"
2. From python you have set [DNSSEC OK bit][2] (`80 00`), from dig it is not set (`00 00`)

As a consequence, server can't fit the whole response (to python query) in 1280 bytes and just returns empty response. 

DIG indicated that it can accept response up to 4096 bytes, and also did not request DNSSEC RRS, so the answer was provided by server (without DNSSEC it would even fit in 1280 bytes). On top of that, dig will by default retry with tcp in case it gets truncated response to the initial udp query.

This dig query should result in the same query to server and (empty) response from the server (compared to python):

    dig bancontact.node1.web1.prod.kunstmaan.com ns  @170.252.72.92 +bufsize=1280 +dnssec +ignore +nocookie

  [1]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6891#section-4.3
  [2]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3225

answers.title: How this JavaScript call stack skip the conditions and execute the rest?

answers.body_markdown:
The concept to understand here is that when a sync function is executed the system waits for a result.

So if a function is nested and calls itself like in your example, it will go like:

 - countdown(2) waits for countdown(1) 
 - countdown(1) waits for countdown(0)
 - countdown(0) sends its result
 - countdown(1) continues and send result
 - countdown(2) continues and send result

Here is the full chain of events:

 - `countdown(2)` is executed
 - outputs `2 A`
 - goes into `if => else` statement
 - outputs `2...`
 - `countdown(1)` is executed
 - outputs `1 A`
 - goes into `if => else` statement
 - outputs `1...`
 - `countdown(0)` is executed
 - outputs `0 A`
 - goes into `if` statement
 - outputs `Done!`
 - goes out of `if` statement
 - outputs `0 C`
 - returns result to `countdown(1)`
 - `countdown(1)` continues its execution
 - outputs `1 B`
 - out of `if => else` statement
 - outputs `1 C`
 - returns result to `countdown(2)`
 - `countdown(2)` continues its execution
 - outputs `2 B`
 - out of `if => else` statement 
 - outputs `2 C`
answers.title: How this JavaScript call stack skip the conditions and execute the rest?

answers.body_markdown:
You have to act like a compiler: decompose the given expression into smaller parts that the hardware can execute.

We can start this decomposition in C, to get a better idea of what we need to do.&nbsp; Like in assembly language, when we decompose, we make simpler statements, *interconnected by temporary variables*.

    s = (a + b) - (c + 101)

Let's do this transformation in C then, introducing temporary variables to connect the simplified parts.

    t1 = a + b
    t2 = c + 101
    s = t1 - t2

This form has a name, [Three Address Code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-address_code).

The MIPS translation of this is pretty straightforward: As the assembly language programmer, we choose a CPU register to the temporary variables, so `t1` from the above C code, might go `$t1` MIPS register, `t2` to `$t2`.&nbsp; (Here we observe that the values for `t1` and `t2` are both needed simultaneously: that is, their lifetimes *overlap*.&nbsp; Thus, they each need their own assembly location, i.e. their own CPU register.)

We also need to know where `a`, `b`, and `c` are located.&nbsp; Let's assume they are parameters in MIPS designated argument CPU registers `$a0`, `$a1`, and `$a2` respectively.

This means that the first line `t1 = a + b`, can translate into a MIPS instruction:

    add $t1, $a0, $a1

and so on:

    addi $t2, $a2, 101    # here we use an "add immediate" since one operand is a constant

and finally, assuming we want `s` in MIPS CPU register `$s1`:

    sub $s1, $t1, $t2

---

The general idea is that in assembly language / machine code, we cannot do everything we want in a single instruction, so we have to break the code down into smaller pieces and use multiple instructions.

We have to understand more detail about locations of variables, and management of temporary values, since the CPU registers are limited to a small number (whereas in C we can have virtually unlimited variables as needed (i.e. for Three Address Coding), and also of course, C can forgo TAC: use parenthesis and operator precedence to hold intermediate values without even naming a temporary variable.).&nbsp; (If we run out of CPU registers in assembly, we have to write code to shuffle values between memory and registers, using memory to hold any overruns.)

Management of registers &#8212; for long-live variables & for short-lived temporaries &#8212; is a big part of the job of writing assembly language.&nbsp; Two variables that have overlapping lifetimes cannot share the same CPU register, yet since the CPU registers are finite, we can run out for larger expressions.&nbsp; On MIPS, there are 10 registers specifically dedicated as temporaries (though there are some other registers, too).&nbsp; We need to know when we are finished with a temporary value, since then its CPU register can be repurposed for something else.
